results.title: We grew a frog
results.creator_credit: Nigel Rea, Peter Boulton and Boulton-Hawker Films
results.brief_description:
Records an activity in which children collect and rear frog spawn in a tank at their school. Covers each stage in the development of the frog, showing details not easily seen in a classroom aquarium.
Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: We found a valley
results.brief_description: An account of the building of a large oil refinery on a strip of sand near Aden in Arabia. Shows the difficulties and local hazards encountered in this engineering achievement.

results.title: We don't make him special
results.creator_credit: Peter Brighton, Joan Reidy, Marjorie Fisher and I E A
results.brief_description: The story of the integration into life’s normal activities of a Down’s syndrome child as related by his mother. The acceptance of the child into the school community is effectively portrayed enabling the program to be utilised by a school contemplating the integration of disabled students. A positive program that supports the belief that the whole community benefits from the integration of disabled people into society.

results.title: We discovered North Norway
results.brief_description: A train trip in the land of the midnight sun, through more than 500 tunnels. Per Host shows the grandeur of Northern Norway, which until recently very few Norwegians had ever seen. It is a geographical anomaly that here, north of the arctic circle, one can sun-bathe and swim in the fjords amid the towering peaks and plunging ravines.

results.title: We can't stand still can we?
results.creator_credit: Ken McCready, Roman Bittman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is about the urban renewal plan drawn up by the town council of High River, Alberta. It saved the town, and could save many others across Canada.

results.title: We can't afford to be casual about child care (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Anne Smith, Michael Milan and Audio Visual Learning Centre, University of Otago
results.brief_description: Child care is discussed by Dr. Bettye Caldwell from the University of Arkansas and Pat Hubbard, director of the Dunedin community child care centre. They discuss whether child care damages mother-child attachment, the importance of an optimal environment for children in early years, the particular qualities and nature of good child care, and the difficulty in financing it

results.title: We call them killers
results.creator_credit: Tom Shandel, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A rare opportunity to observe two killer whales, Haida and Chimo, kept at the time of filming at the Victoria Sealand of the Pacific Aquarium. Far from any show of ferocity, the huge mammals display a sense of fun and rapport with their trainers, especially during their performances for the public. Dr. Paul Spong, noted cetologist, describes his attempts at inter-species communication. Musician Paul Horn captivates Haida with the sounds of his flute.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tom Shandel, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: We call it paradise
results.creator_credit: Vincent Donovan and Australia. Dept. of Defence
results.brief_description: Niree Creed presents this portrait of Garden Island, 6 km. south of Perth and the effect the construction of HMAS Stirling, a naval base, has had on the island and on the town of Rockingham. The construction of the base caused some controversy as squatters, who had lived there for many years, were removed in the process. This film, produced by Defence Public Relations emphasises the benefits the base has brought to the local community.

results.title: We believe in it...We know it's true
results.brief_description: This program, narrated by Ian Dunlop, was filmed in 1982 at Yirrkala on the Gove Peninsula in the Northern Territory. Yirrkala was established as a Methodist mission in 1935, but today is an Aboriginal township. This is a film about the importance of cultural continuity in this Aboriginal community. It records funeral ceremonies, traditional dances and songs. It also examines the special educational programs to inform white Territorians about the culture of their Aboriginal neighbours and to educate Aboriginal children in their own language at Yirrkala school.
